      90          32 :   async execute (cmd, ...args) {
      91             :     // if we had a command timer running, clear it now that we're starting
      92             :     // a new command and so don't want to time out
      93          57 :     if (this.noCommandTimer) {

      95             :     }
      96             : 
      97             :     // if we don't have this command, it must not be implemented
      98             :     if (!this[cmd]) {
      99             :       throw new errors.NotYetImplementedError();

     101             : 
     102             :     // What we're doing here is pretty clever. this.curCommand is always
     103             :     // a promise representing the command currently being executed by the
     104             :     // driver, or the last command executed by the driver (it starts off as
     105             :     // essentially a pre-resolved promise). When a command comes in, we tack it
     106             :     // to the end of this.curCommand, essentially saying we want to execute it
     107             :     // whenever this.curCommand is done. We call this new promise nextCommand,
     108             :     // and its resolution is what we ultimately will return to whomever called
     109             :     // us. Meanwhile, we reset this.curCommand to _be_ nextCommand (but
     110           7 :     // ignoring any rejections), so that if another command comes into the
     111           7 :     // server, it gets tacked on to the end of nextCommand. Thus we create
     112           7 :     // a chain of promises that acts as a queue with single concurrency.
     113          57 :     let nextCommand = this.curCommand.then(() => {
     114          57 :       return this[cmd](...args);
     115             :     });
     116          57 :     this.curCommand = nextCommand.catch(() => {});
     117          56 :     let res = await nextCommand;
     118          11 : 
     119          11 :     // if we have set a new command timeout (which is the default), start a

     121          11 :     // the timer (which is done when a new command comes in), we will trigger
     122          11 :     // automatic session deletion in this.onCommandTimeout. Of course we don't
     123             :     // want to trigger the timer when the user is shutting down the session
     124          11 :     // intentionally
